w:r.w:t: This document outlines the standard Service Level Agreement (SLA) between
(the "Service Provider") and its clients (the "Customer"). It is subject to periodic review to ensure it remains aligned with business needs and industry best practices.
Updated company name and service hours; added specific change management targets.
Added Expedited Standard Change; updated Governance section with TAM & vCISO terminology.
This is a Service Level Agreement (SLA) between

. This document identifies the services required and the expected level of service between One2call Limited and the Customer. It serves as the primary tool for managing expectations and creating a shared understanding of responsibilities, timelines, and outcomes.
The purpose of this SLA is to specify the requirements of the IT Managed Services provided by One2call Limited with regards to:
A clear and measurable description of the service provision.
Agreed-upon service targets for service desk incidents and change requests.
The roles and responsibilities of both One2call Limited and the Customer.
The procedures for reporting, escalation, and governance.
The duration, scope, and review cadence of this agreement.
This SLA covers the following services provided by One2call Limited:
Support for personal (non-company-owned) devices, unless covered by a premium service tier.
Service Level Agreement: A documented agreement between a service provider and a customer that defines the level of service expected.
Information Technology Infrastructure Library: A globally recognised framework of best practices for IT Service Management.
An unplanned interruption to an IT service or reduction in the quality of an IT service.
The addition, modification, or removal of anything that could have a direct or indirect effect on IT services.
Request for Change: A formal proposal for a change to be implemented.
Change Advisory Board: A group of people that
supports the assessment, prioritisation, authorisation, and scheduling of changes.
7:00 AM to 7:00 PM, Monday to Friday.
Our team is available to take calls, respond to emails, and log tickets during this period.
8:00 AM to 6:00 PM, Monday to Friday, excluding public holidays.
All SLA time-based targets (Response and Resolution) are measured within these hours.
Provide the services as defined within the scope of this agreement.
Meet the response and resolution times as outlined in the service targets.
Inform the Customer regarding scheduled and unscheduled service outages as necessary.
Provide regular performance reports and conduct periodic service reviews.
Manage the change process to minimise disruption to the Customer's services.
Provide all necessary information and assistance to allow One2call Limited to meet its performance standards.
Inform One2call Limited of any business changes that may impact the services covered by this SLA (e.g., new office locations, significant changes in user count).
Ensure its users adhere to company IT policies and procedures.
Appoint a primary contact for escalations and approvals.
This section defines the commitments for managing and resolving unplanned service interruptions (Incidents).
5.1. The Priority Matrix: Translating Technical Issues into Business Impact
All incidents are categorised using a priority matrix to ensure that issues with the greatest business impact are addressed first.
Priority is determined by assessing an incident's
(the extent of the issue's effect on the business) and
(the speed at which the issue will negatively affect the business).
A major business disruption affecting all or a significant majority of users. Business operations are halted.
Total network failure, primary server crash, entire organisation unable to send/receive email.
A significant business disruption affecting a large group of users or a department. A workaround may exist.
CRM system inaccessible to the sales team, departmental file server offline.
A limited business disruption. An individual user is unable to work effectively, or a non-critical function is failing.
Single user's computer failing to start, network printer unavailable.
Minimal or no business disruption. Minor technical issues or "how-to" questions.
Request to change an email signature, question about a software feature.
5.2. The SLA Clock: Our Key Metrics Defined
The journey of a support ticket is measured by three key milestones:
The time from when a ticket is created to when an automated confirmation is sent to the user. This confirms the request has been logged in our system.
The time from ticket creation until a qualified engineer has reviewed the ticket, confirmed its priority, and begun active work on resolving the issue. This is marked by the first meaningful,
The total time from ticket creation until the service has been fully restored, confirmed with the user, and the ticket is closed.

The SLA clock will be temporarily paused when resolution is dependent on factors outside of our direct control. The clock resumes as soon as the dependency is met. This ensures fair and accurate performance measurement.
Waiting for a response, information, or testing from the Customer.
Waiting for action from an external third-party vendor (e.g., an ISP or software manufacturer).
5.3. Our Service Level Targets for Incidents
The following table outlines our standard SLA targets for incidents, measured during
SLA Measurement Hours (8:00 AM - 6:00 PM, Mon-Fri)
The primary objective of our Change Management process is to enable beneficial changes to be made with minimum disruption to IT services, governed by the ITIL framework.
This is achieved through a controlled process of risk assessment, planning, and authorisation.
We classify changes into three types to manage risk effectively
Changes that require formal review and authorisation before implementation.
Urgent changes required to resolve a major incident.
Low-risk, frequently performed activities that follow a documented, pre-authorised procedure.
Because their risk is minimal, they do not require individual CAB approval.
Creating a new user account, installing a pre-approved application, replacing a keyboard.
. Requests are typically submitted via our service catalogue.
Non-emergency modifications that are not pre-authorised and require a formal Request for Change (RFC) to be submitted for risk assessment and CAB approval.
Upgrading a core business application, migrating a server, implementing a new firewall.
. This is the minimum number of days an RFC must be submitted
of the planned implementation date to allow for proper planning and risk assessment.
Changes that must be implemented with extreme urgency to resolve a major incident or remediate a critical security vulnerability.
Applying a patch for a zero-day exploit, restoring a database to resolve a service outage.
The SLA is tied directly to the associated
. The formal process is bypassed for speed, with documentation completed retrospectively.
A pre-authoris ed, low-risk change that is blocking a user or business process. (e.g., Admin password needed for urgent task).
Pre-authoris ed. No individual approval needed.
New user creation, approved software install).
Pre-authoris ed. No individual approval needed.
A non-urgent change requiring formal review. (e.g., Server upgrade, application migration).
An urgent change to resolve a major incident. (e.g.,
Implemented immediately to meet P1 incident resolution SLA.
changes, a formal Request for Change (RFC) must be submitted. This ensures all changes are properly documented, assessed for risk, and approved, which is critical for maintaining service stability.
The RFC should contain the following information:
A unique identifier for tracking purposes.
The person responsible for the change project.
The priority level of the change (e.g., High, Medium, Low).
A clear outline of the IT services, software, or hardware that will be changed.
The business case and justification for why the change is needed.
The expected positive impacts (e.g., ROI) and potential negative impacts of the change.
An outline of the risks identified (e.g., potential downtime) and the steps taken to mitigate them (e.g., back-out plan, testing).
The target date for the change.
One2call Limited will provide the Customer with a monthly performance report detailing performance against all SLA metrics.
Regular service review meetings, which we refer to as
, will be held to discuss performance, review strategic alignment, and plan for future requirements.
For customers on our premium package, this service may be enhanced to include a
who provides strategic guidance on cybersecurity and compliance alignment.
This SLA is a living document. It will be formally reviewed at least annually, or when significant business changes occur, to ensure it remains relevant and effective.
Any amendments must be mutually agreed upon by both parties.
By signing below, both parties agree to the terms and conditions outlined in this Service Level Agreement.
